body: @kevinthesun Is the shape of `valid_counts` `[num_batch]`? how do you set `valid_counts` in TF/Keras frontend? Setting `valid_counts` to a constant array won't work because you can't use TVM expr to subscript a python/numpy array

@srkreddy1238 I have added support to relay as well.

Expressing gradients in relay would be a good design test. My thoughts regarding this design choice are follows:
- I am not sure that all listed operations have gradients which may be expressed in Relay language currently. Ideally we should move towards creating a list of basic operations which form a closed set in the sense that they have gradients expressible in themselves. 
- Expressing gradients in relay may foster Relay's C++ API.
- As an option, one may implement operations in Relay (in addition to provide its FTVMCompute attribute). This way It would become a subject to relay's differentiation engine. `dense`, `softmax` are possible candidates for this approach.

Let me try to rename list -> seq, and do a bidirectional-rnn using mapAccumL and mapAccumR. Thanks @wweic for help!

I copy-pasted the definition of List<a> to Seq<a>, which may be more attractive to NLP researchers. (although there is no difference)

```
data Seq<a> {
   Nil : () -> Seq
   Cons : (a, Seq[a]) -> Seq
}
```

An RNNCell is a function that maps (old state `s`, input `x`) -> (new state `s'`, output `y'`), where both states have exactly the state type (shape, dtype, etc).

```
def @RNNCell<state_type, in_type, out_type>(%s : state_type, %x : in_type) -> (state_type, out_type) {
}
```

Encoding the sequence uni-directionally means applying RNNCell from left to right. Additionally, the bi-rnn encodes the sequence again from right to left. In the end, the representation of each token in the sequence is zipped by the left-to-right and right-to-left representation.

```
zip (mapAccumR rnn_cell_0 state_0 input) (mapAccumL rnn_cell_1 state_1 input)
```

For what it is worth, the posit number system restores associative and distributive properties for floating point. The culprit is IEEE floating point rounding rules. The solution requires special hardware which is available as of Dec 2017, and we are trying to incorporate this hw into VTA. The benefit is significant: an 8-bit posit beats a 32-bit IEEE float in terms of training accuracy. And since most models are memory bound, we get a big boost in performance as well. Of course, an 8-bit posit is still slower than an 8-bit integer.

@FrozenGene We can provide defaults for all pass meta-data including defaulting to no scheduling of the pass at all. I believe we should also include a `-Fpass` style mechanism to enable and disable individual passes as well. The current build_config interface doesn't allow us to fully remove, add, and order passes. 

Particularly I feel reaching consensus and moving forward soon would be good. @zhiics has been blocked on our discussion and the lack of a manger. 

I caught @tqchen for an in-person chat at the end of last week, and will summarize the results of our conversation below.

In the interest of moving forward  with the pass manager I think we should all weigh this update, and move towards an implementation. My recommendation is that we do it in two pieces first adding a simple manager, a pass wrapper class, and the basic pass signature and registration in an initial PR.

Then follow up with a secondary PR in which we convert all existing passes to work in this style, and provide user facing APIs for writing & registering passes. 

@tqchen wants to standardize on a single pass signature that is shared across all passes, and his ideal signature is `Module -> Module` the challenge with this signature is how to share state across passes. In general I think stateless passes are good, but traditional compilers often share state between passes.  Tianqi commented that we have avoided sharing any state in our current set of passes and will not be a problem. 

The concern I continued to raise during our conversation is that if we commit to this signature and *do* need to share state it will be challenging, and painful to readapt the code. We can of course write mini-passes that explicitly share state, but lose the ability to treat them as independent passes from the pass manager's point of view.

We also discussed whether we should have a `Pass` class or not. My feeling is whether we expose this interface to the user or not we should internally store a pass class which wraps a pass function with the required meta-data. I think we can address @FrozenGene's concern by accepting functions which match the pass signature in the interface.

After thinking about it over the weekend I'm further convinced that we need more state than a  module to do even simple things like descriptive errors.

For example if we make use of span based errors (yet to be implemented) we need to carry around the source map, a piece of state not accounted for in this design. Even in the current error reporting we must know both the module, and function we are in, which are contained in the module, but this may not always be the case.

In the world where we have a `Module -> Module` signature users can manually construct an error reporter, but this does not provide an abstraction, all pass authors must understand how to correctly initialize and use the reporting. The lack of abstraction provides us no means to expose a higher level API hiding details we may want to change for 3rd party pass authors. 

Asking users to manually configure what should be standard pieces of infrastructure increases the burden to build a pass. I fear this may lead to sub-standard passes which don't make use of features due to development burden of having to, resulting in passes which do not match the interaction provided by the rest of the system. 

I don't believe error reporting is the last time we will see such a pattern and fixing the wrong design now will make it hard to support these use cases. 

One alternative I proposed is to provide call operators on the passes which act as factory methods. These would setup up the pass with the appropriate state and allow use to take state while providing an easy to use interface that works over a single Module, or Expression.

To conclude I think we should reach consensus on an internal signature, not necessarily the API users will interact with in Python or C++, but how the pass will be defined, configured, and invoked by the manager. 

To respond to @yzhliu I think for now everything we put in the state would be mutable, we could choose to make `realay::Module` immutable but currently modules and error reporting are some of the *only mutable* types in Relay.

@junrushao1994 if porting the RNN example to a functional style is giving you any trouble or taking too much of your time, it would be fine if you gave an imperative version; I would be more than happy to express it using folds. (In fact, the imperative version would be good for an illustrative example.)
@masahi yes, I'm trying to solve the data race. sorry I was on vacation, will pick up this soon

Some summary of my takes:

- The signature of the Pass.operator()(or``` __call__``` in python) should be ```Module->Module``` to minimize the simplicity
- We can provide meta-data about passes to allow the manager to automatically compose pass together. The meta-data provides the declarative fashion to compose up things, just like nn.Module
- The composed pass should, in turn, should expose the same signature ```Module->Module```

The main reason that I think we should have a clean unified signature(Module->Module) in the case of  ```__call__```, is that it provides a simple way for a user to try out things imperatively.

## What if a Pass Need Other States
First of all, we need to distinguish two kinds of requirements:
- Context states: error reporter belongs to this category
- Real information that needs to be passed.

Context states are internal to each pass, and we just need to be able to quickly construct them when constructing pass functions, and provide utils to do smart error reporting.

Let us see the case of real state information, consider the following case:
```python
module = relay.from_frontend(model)
aux_info = relay.ir_pass.some_aux_analysis(module)
transformed = relay.ir_pass.pass_func1(module, aux_info)
```

- In most of our current analysis, it suffices to fold aux_info and the pass_func1 together as a Pass. 
- Alternatively, we can declare in the pass function that the pass_func1 requires the additional aux information, and let the pass manager handles the call to aux_analysis.

The advantage of the second approach is it somehow enables sharing of aux_info if we can build that incrementally even after we change the module. On the other hand, atm we can simply rebuild things from scratch.

In both cases, regardless of which design we choose, we do not necessarily have to make the pass signature ```Module, Info->Module, Info```. Instead, the "internal siganture" could take ```Module, Info ->Module```` where the second or more argument indicates additional information requested. Since we cannot really enumerate this information at the moment.

Regardless of what we do, I do think that from a high-level user should only care about Module->Module, this will make composition much cleaner, and avoids an additional concept burden(PassState) which can cause confusion in most cases
+1 apache is a good way to go.
@tqchen API updated.

okay, it looks I can probably summarize our great discussion as follows:

- I think we are actually kind of having `Module->Module` optimizations as `PassState` includes `Module` and other information. The question is wether or not we need to only pass `Module` and keep other information internal, meaning we can make `PassState` internal (to C++) and let it contain only internal information.
- Each `Pass` object should have a `PassInfo` or `PassMeta` class including metadata like pass name, opt_level, enabled, required_passes, etc. (This is good. It was also under my plan).
- Do we still need `FunctionPass` and `ExprPass`? I think we need them.

Please correct me or add anything that I missunderstood or missed.

While I do not doubt that the current proposal can expose the same interface, we still need to discuss the internal interface "pass signature" mentioned by @jroesch. 

It is always easy to get more by adding another layer of abstraction, but we want the minimum one. As I may quote "The best design is achieved not when there is nothing to add, but when there is nothing to be taken away".

Now back to the internal signature design, there are a few questions:
- Do we really need PassState? 
   - I think we can remove this concept, and make most of the signature (Module, NodeRef->Module) (this allows PassInfo to be optional and anything).
- Do we need PassMeta?
  - Alternatively, meta information can be just part of a virtual function interface in the Pass.
- Do we need PassFunc vs Pass, or simply Pass as a virtual base is fine?
-  Do we still need `FunctionPass` and `ExprPass`, this really boils down to how passes are implemented.
  - In the context of LLVM, we need them because passes are applied per scope. In the context of deep learning, while I can see the need for applying things per Function, we do not yet have too much need for applying things per Expr.
   - I recommend we defer since these are details that are not part of the interface

Concerning using int32/int64 for indices, I think we should create a separate, conceptually unbounded integer type for index arithmetic. Ideally, in compile-time we should use some arbitrary precision integer library for it, but using int64 may do as a starting point. (And of course it should be represented with int32/64 in run-time).

@tqchen I think this is very important direction to improve. Have you thought about using existing libraries like ISL? As far as I know it contains many useful algorithms and, more importantly, well-defined notation for describing formulas and relations of variables.

re conceptual integer index. I think moving toward int64 as default and do optional narrowing is a good starting point as @sgrechanik-h  pointed out.

re ISL. My understanding of isl is that it tries to do exact integer set analysis, and uses a constraint solver based approach(although I am not an expert in isl). As a result, it has some restrictions in terms of operation, as well as speed of solving.

In our case, we aim at providing simple forward solving ways for relaxed integer set analysis. Integer set abstraction and pushing most analysis to integer set primitives are important, and we should learn that perspective from isl. 

On the other hand, I think the first pass of scaffolding should aim to build a self-contained analyzer. Then we can see if there is value to bring isl as an optional sub-anlayzer.
Thanks @mjs-arm , this is now merged

A good set of changes. Note that we do not need to make hybrid dump optional. The reason that random and NNPack are optional is that they are linked into the runtime library and have additional dependencies. 

Hybrid dump is a compiler feature, that you should add to COMPILER_SRCS by default

I have reservation about this code change. It seems to me this is too much a cost of increased risk and code complexity for something not of too much practical value, e.g., number of bits exceeds max int32. You end up having code which uses int32 in one case and int64 in another? Super confusing! If number of bits exceeds max int32 you likely have other problem to worry about, like, unable to allocate memory that big.

I suggest either this should be left not fixed. Or fix in more conservative way, like using unsigned int32 instead of signed, so you can have up to 4 billion bits. Or if you feel strongly about supporting more than 4 billion bits, uniformly use int64. Just don't have a mixed case of int32/int64 which is too risky.

@Anthony-Mai has some point on this. Perhaps a simple way forward is to first use a CHECK to make sure we do not go OOM and use int32 atm. As discussed in #2588 , we want to transition to int64 once we have a proper narrowing pass that detects the best data types, and we can move on from there

@Anthony-Mai Thanks for your comment. I think allocating more than 2G or even 4G memory on a 64-bit system should be okay. We have an usage that requires a large amount of memory. We are also probably going to test very large input images on some networks, where uint32 might not be enough.

I am not sure if we need to use int64 all around the other places because it seems that VTA at least only uses int32, it would result in many casts. In addition, as per @yzhliu comment, we are warning the users here. I understand that using one consistent type is ideal, but casting as needed in this case is more like a small optimization. Anyway, I am happy to hear other voices. @tqchen @yzhliu @wweic
@tqchen Sorry, I didn't see your comment above. It seems we sent around the same time... Please take another look. But it seems we need more than max int32 to support the usage.
I think we all agree on fixing the problem. The question is should we fix it now or wait and come back to fix it after we transition most defaults from int32->int64 and apply optimal narrowing.
Does uint32 work? If so this can be a valid fix which satisfy both the special use case @zhiics and the team met so far, and avoiding type mismatch.
@yzhliu uint32 should be enough for that special case. NVM, for even larger tests, I think we might be able to wait till everything is fixed. Let me change it to uint32.
I would advise against uint32, int64 is a better choice mainly because the additional 1 bit wont really bring too much benefit
Given that we are moving toward relay. Let us simply move the nnvm tutorials into tutorials/nnvm and remove the relay subtile on the relay tutorials
To be honest, I personally also think int64 is better. uint32 doesn't change anything in this context because they are still different types.
okay, if nobody disagrees, I will change it back to int64.
oh I thought with uint32 we can avoid mismatch. If not I'm good with the i64 fix. Let's also track it in #2588

Thanks for the pointer to the blog post, I have ported over C. Olah's examples to Relay, but I am not sure I understood the RNN cell code correctly, so I would appreciate review of the examples. They perhaps do not make for a very flattering portrait of Relay, since we don't have currying (and do not want it) and presently don't deconstruct tuples in match expressions (that might be something we want, though), so a lot of the code looks bulkier than the corresponding Haskell. I would appreciate any review of the new section I added.

I've updated the PR with a Relay integration. Basically, calling `relay._ir_pass.AutogeneratePrimalGradientForAll()` will populate the FPrimalGradient attribute of every relay operation with automatically generated gradients. For some operations automatically generated gradients fail with compile or run-time errors, usually this is caused by multi-output operations (which don't seem to be fully supported by the relay ad yet) and by integer inputs and outputs.

I've updated the tensor expression AD PR with a Relay integration, [here](https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/pull/2498#issuecomment-464163692). The commit itself is [here](https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/pull/2498/commits/cf5083a81072c72cedd14433d6ce90e744b216f7).

Quick naive questions @tqchen 

If an external library wants to inherit tvm arrays, and we don't want to modify TVM's codebase

1. Does it inherit `tvm::runtime::NDArray`, or `tvm::runtime::NDArray::Container`, or both? (Looks like it is enough to inherit the container, since NDArray is just a thin layer of the container?)
2. In which part of a frontend should the ext lib inquiry the flag `array_type_index_`?
@kevinthesun What's the difference between `return_indices` in proposed API and `selected_indices` in TF/Pytorch?
Shall we also add bug-fixes into the list?

@Laurawly Actually TF always return `selected_indices`, and they expect users to `tf.gather` boxes by these returned indices. I suppose @kevinthesun is going to support both behavior, either return boxes or indices by flag `return_indices`
is #2535 the blocking PR to this one? GluonCV is planning to integrate deeper with TVM support for inference, so this PR is critical to our next steps.

@junrushao1994 I agree with 1 that inheriting the container only will suffice.

If inherit both, maybe they share some attributes, which should be maintained on both sides. This is not good for further maintenance.

If something like an `extern::NDArray` is desired, a `tvm::NDArray` can be created and referred by an `extern::Container`.

The only counter-intuitive part of doing this is that: when garbage collection, `tvm::NDArray` and `tvm::Container` free its space when `ref_count_ == 1`; however, for the `extern::NDArray`, it should be freed when `ref_count_ == 2`; at this point, we are going to free the last `extern::Container` and after that the origin `tvm::NDArray` can be freed.

`extern::NDArray` will be a subclass of `tvm::NDArray`. `extern::NDArray::Container` will be a subclass of `tvm::NDArray::Container`.

I don't understand the `ref_count` thing. Doesn't seem to be right...
Hey @nhynes, any update on your PR? No rush, just curious
From the C++ side, if we want `TVMArgValue` to be able to automatically convert to `extern::NDArray`, the `TVMArgValue` probably needs access to `array_type_index_`.
Probably we need a method like `As<Type>()`, in which the `tvm::NDArray` checks whether `Type::array_type_index` matches its `data_->array_type_index_`.
